1110215381954650114.text:
How to get an incoming channel from any peer using Loop Out
1. Make a channel with any peer
2. Loop Out, with channelid= that channel
3. Channel balance is now on the other side
Specifying a channel with Loop Out is the way to make sure you receive the inbound liquidity you want.

1109110036373004288.text:
Loop Out vs alternatives for getting inbound liquidity
- Custodial swaps: custodial risk
- Purchase channel: potentially higher cost, more centralized
- Buy stuff: could be slow, but cheap
- Freebie from mass capital: probable routing failures
- Advertise: requires social capital

1108405067592302592.text:
Thrilled to see reverse Submarine Swaps in production https://github.com/lightninglabs/loop …

It only works on lnd master so you’d need to migrate to that

It’s important to understand that chain and channel transactions are synergistic. Chans do some things well and chains do other things well

1108406146929512448.text: It uses "submarine swaps". The two parties involved use a swap provider, which is 100% trustless as the swap provider is never a custodian or in a position to act maliciously. Accomplished using HTLCs per usual, the only difference is one is on-chain and one is off-chain

1108402547126161409.text: New service that allows you to obtain inbound liquidity on any channel you like. You can pick your peer based on its routing policy, so that others (your customers for example) paying you through the channel later on will pay a fair routing fee.https://twitter.com/lightning/status/1108398809481003008 …

1108401145825902593.text: This is a very clever way to increase a channel's inbound capacity without having to make any changes in L1. In essence, this eases channel management (especially for merchants), as it allows you to offload the balance of your channel to a wallet *without having to close it*https://twitter.com/lightning/status/1108398809481003008 …

1067725622095564800.text: Defense in depth is important. Most of the @lightning app’s attack surface is in the JavaScript code (and npm dependencies) that’s sandboxed in Electron’s rendering process. Lnd runs in a separate child process (which holds the user’s private key): https://blog.lightning.engineering/posts/2018/11/27/app-security.html …

1006683504451522560.text: Ah submarine swap is an on-chain payment that purchases a LN payment: The sender locks funds into a conditional script, where either the swap provider can spend the funds by providing a pre-image, thus proving to have paid the LN invoice, or sender can take it back themselves.

1006682660834426880.text: A Hash-Timelocked-Contract is a conditional payment on a LN channel with two possible outcomes: Either the recipient provides the pre-image corresponding to the Lightning invoice that is being paid and takes the funds, or after the lock times out, the sender takes back the funds.https://twitter.com/bradmillscan/status/1006665134675255296 …

1006615544643162114.text: Even knowing how LN works, watching frenzied activity on http://satoshis.place  made me wonder about the mempool. 960746904735789057.text:
AMP: Atomic Multi-Path Payments over Lightning

https://lists.linuxfoundation.org/pipermail/lightning-dev/2018-February/000993.html …

A common Lightning question is: “I have five $2 channels, can I *atomically* send a single $6 payment?”. For those that didn't know, the answer is YES! We (@bitconner and I) describe the *how*.

959887723573080065.text:
some quick maths from @bitconner on optimizing a quadratic factor out of our Sphinx packet construction: https://lists.linuxfoundation.org/pipermail/lightning-dev/2018-February/000981.html …

new optimized code: https://github.com/lightningnetwork/lightning-onion/pull/18 …

results in an order of magnitude speed up during routing packet construction!
